text:
MICHAEL LEPECH: It's really
a pleasure to be here today and to host this webinar.

Our product management
program is one of the programs that we're most proud of here
in the School of Engineering

and at Stanford because we
find it to be content that's so relevant to what many
learners are looking

to move into today. For those that end up
taking our program,

you'll learn more
about my background as a startup
entrepreneur and product

manager at my own startups,
building products and getting

them out, and selling them,
in addition to my background being a faculty member in
both the School of Engineering

and the School of
Sustainability here at Stanford. But enough about me.

I'm actually more interested to
have our guests for this webinar

today introduce themselves. And then we'll dive
into some questions.

And then ultimately give you all
a chance to ask some questions.

For those that do have questions
throughout the program, please actively put them into
the Q&A box on the platform.

We'll look to get to as many
of your questions and inquiries as we can by the
end of this webinar.

So without further
ado, Kunal, we'll start with you why don't
you introduce yourself

and then we'll
get-- and then we'll get on to the rest
of the webinar. KUNAL GARG: Sounds great. Thanks so much for
having me, Mike.

Hi, everyone my name is Kunal. I started my career doing
product work at Redfin.

I worked for a couple of years
as an engineer at Wealthfront. And currently, I am the
cofounder and CTO at Bracket.

Bracket is a YC-backed startup. We help sync ops tools like
Salesforce, Google Sheets

with your engineering
databases and data warehouses. I've been part of the XPROD300
Product Management Program

since the beginning. So it's been a
couple of years now and I've enjoyed
this entire process. Excited to chat today.

MICHAEL LEPECH: Sweet. Thank you very much
for joining us. Arya, please go ahead
and introduce yourself.

ARYA TAYLOR: Yeah. Hi, everyone, my name is Arya. I have been a product
manager for four years.

And prior to that, I was
a data scientist, which is how I started out my career.

And I have also been part of
the Product Management Course

at Stanford since the beginning. And that course really-- part of that course is just
us pulling from our real life

experiences and turning that
into something that people can learn from and grow from.

So I'm excited to talk to
you all today about the world of product management. MICHAEL LEPECH: Cool. Well, the first thing I'd
like to ask both of you

to comment on before we get
into our specific questions is you are both actively
involved in our program.

And what exactly do you
do as part of our program? Because I think it's
helpful for learners

to understand how in
addition to learning from great faculty
and other instructors,

how they're going to
interact with someone like you throughout the program. What is it you do?

Let's start with--
let's start with Kunal. KUNAL GARG: OK. So as a coach, a
facilitator for the program,

we help design a lot of the
content and the syllabus

for the course. Some of the material
comes from-- Billy illustrated PMs that have
outlined some of the material

that you'll be
learning and watching. But we will help digest some
of that information in coaching sessions.

So these are weekly
hour-long sessions where we go through
real life examples

and exercises for you to really
understand the learnings.

We also help design some
homework and grade assignments so that you can get
feedback and apply that

to any of your future
endeavors in the product space. So try and guiding you-- try to
get you to experience product

management through this
mini-course that condenses information in a way that gets
you primed to be a product
manager in the real world. MICHAEL LEPECH: Totally. Arya, anything to add to that? ARYA TAYLOR: Yeah.

I would just add that we get
really detailed in our feedback. We are literally going through
your assignments line-by-line,

leaving comments. We offer office
hours if you ever need it to talk about not
just the assignments, but even

your career and what
you want to do next. And for certain learners,
I've reviewed their resume

and helped out there. So there's tons of great ways
to connect with all the coaches.

And it's been great so far. I can definitely see that. I can see a transformation
from the beginning

to the end of the course
from a lot of the learners. MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah.

I couldn't agree more on that. One of the places where I see
your involvement being most

valuable, and it really goes
back to a word that Arya used, experience, and Kunal
mention as well.

We want this to be-- we
structured this program to absolutely be
experiential learning.

And one of the
biggest pieces of that is the Capstone
presentation where we'll put you together in
product teams with folks

from other companies or
even from around the world and give you a product idea or
you can bring your own product

idea to develop something
during the program and then getting that detailed
feedback that we talked about.

How to actually apply
the lessons and the tools right away during the
program is one of the places

that have the most fun. And towards the
end of the program when I'm reviewing Capstone
presentations by the teams,

it's always remarkable
to see the growth of every one of the participants
and the fingerprints

of our coaches,
like Kunal and Arya on making them successful
in learning the content

and then becoming much
more valuable in their job

and better at what they do. So we'll get back a little bit
later to some of the program stuff because I know there are
some questions already coming up

in the Q&A. But I want to get
to the content for this webinar around top skills of a product
manager and how to develop them.

And so we'll start
this time with Arya. What would you say
are your top three

skills as a product manager
and why are these your biggies?

ARYA TAYLOR: It's very difficult
to condense it to three but I will do my best. I think the top
three skills are ones

that I thought I use
day-to-day in my role and I think you'll
hear across the board.

So the first one
is user empathy. And this doesn't mean that
you hear about user problems

and you feel sorry for them
and you want to solve it. It's more like you're able to
really dig into the pain points

that users are having, you're
able to assess the situation, and come up with that
true core problem.

Because you're going to hear
users say different things but you need to be
able to translate that into something very actionable.

And this doesn't just
limit it to users. You also need
empathy for everyone

that you interact with at work. You're going to have other teams
that you're partnering with.

You're going to be talking
to leadership, engineers, designers, and you need to
have empathy for where they're

coming from and be able to
meet them where they're at and assess those
situations as well.

So I would say that
is the first skill. MICHAEL LEPECH:
Number one, empathy. And it's probably not
a surprise that that's

where another very Stanford
thing, the design thinking framework starts as well.

ARYA TAYLOR: What
a great coincidence because I didn't know that. [LAUGHTER] MICHAEL LEPECH: Me too.

ARYA TAYLOR: Number two,
being a good communicator. So like I said, you
interface with users,

you interface with
leadership, your stakeholders, everyone you could
possibly think of.

You interface with
people that where English is their second language
or maybe their third language.

You interface with
people that may have a lot of
technical knowledge or don't have any
technical knowledge

and as a product
manager, you have to, again, meet them
where they're at and be able to communicate
clearly across the board.

I can just share a
quick example of what happens when that goes wrong.

Recently, I was on an
email thread with my CEO and I missed one word.

Instead of saying all
clients, I just said clients and it got taken completely out
of context and people started

thinking that there was a
huge problem that happened, so on and so forth all because
I missed that one word.

So it's really important
to be super, super detailed and thorough in
your communication

so that you don't cause
these ripple effects and you're able to get that
alignment with your team

members and your company. So that's number two. MICHAEL LEPECH: I guess
maybe I would also

say that communication can
also be extended to translation

or interpretation because you're
probably working with people with very different
skill sets who

use different words to
describe similar things. And in addition to maybe English
not being the first language,

engineering versus marketing
being the first language. And so we can interpret language
as a variety of different ways

and so communication
and translation across job roles
within your PM team

is probably also
a piece of that. ARYA TAYLOR: Definitely. I think that's a
great way to put it.

MICHAEL LEPECH: And so
what's number three? ARYA TAYLOR: Yes. Number three is you have
to be a deep thinker.

And I think this is where the
meat of what a PM really does comes into play.

So when you think about a PM
and who they're mapped to, they're mapped to an
engineering team, a design team, the engineers are building,
the designers are designing,

but what are you doing as a PM? Sometimes you feel
like, oh, well, I'm just in the middle of this all
I'm not really doing anything.

But your job is really to
be a very deep thinker. You need to be critically
assessing all of the information

that you're getting, be able
to synthesize those learnings, be able to come up with
a vision, a roadmap,

and really turn
problems into solutions. You need to take into
data into account.

You need to take user
research into account. There's a lot of
inputs coming your way along with the
company's strategy, what

are the constraints. Maybe one of your engineers
has to take a month off.

Maybe COVID hits and your
company strategy changes.

There's always things
at play and you need to be deeply thinking
about all of those things

to be able to make
the best decisions. So I think that's really
the top three skills that I

feel any good PM should have. MICHAEL LEPECH: Super cool. Kunal, have you got
some different ones

or do you want to add
on to any of those? KUNAL GARG: Yeah. Those are really strong ones. I feel like the user
empathy is definitely

number one on every PM's list. That is probably the most
important skill to hone.

I do have maybe three
that lend to more of the startup lens or early
stage entrepreneurship product

lens. So my three would be
the ability to wear

many hats, being organized, and
being decisive but open minded.

I can dig a little
deeper on each of those.

With being able
to wear many hats, I think especially
in the startup space,

typically you might be
the only PM or an early PM where there might not be
a full user research team,

there might not be
a full sales team, there might not be a full
design, data science team

and it's your job to
kind of fill in the gaps that your team needs and still
synthesize and think critically,

like Arya was saying,
across those different teams to come to a clear product
vision and product strategy.

So I feel like I've
heard it a lot. You have to wear a lot of
hats to be a successful PM.

MICHAEL LEPECH: This
goes back to something that Arya had said about being
a good communicator right

and being able to be that
bridge between a bunch

of different folks. And when you're
working with them, they want to see you
wearing a hat that's similar to what they wear as
well because that just makes it

easier for that empathy
to grow between you and those members of your team.

KUNAL GARG: 100%. Yeah, you have to
jump into their world and see it from their lens.

you're setting up a
project from day zero, you have to have good
systems in place.

And if you're going to be
hiring folks and leading a team towards a
specific vision,

I think having
those good systems, being regimented
about these processes

allows everyone on
the team to feel like there's a cohesive goal
that we're working towards.

It helps also if you can
organize the team such that you're unblocking
them as well.

The more organization, the
more systems you have in place, you are able to
unblock your teammates

so that they can be successful
in their specific functions as well. And I think it's
an important thing to protect your
engineers' time so

that they can be successful
in their specific tasks.

So yeah-- MICHAEL LEPECH:
Yeah, your third one was all about being
decisive but open minded.

KUNAL GARG: Yeah. So I felt this was a
super important skill

in the super early
stages of startups.

When we embarked on
the startup journey, we actually were building in
a completely different space.

We were building in the creator
economy, the gig economy. And we learned pretty
quickly that we

have to commit to some specific
product or problem space

and then try to invalidate or
validate as quickly as possible because time is a
limited resource.

And that philosophy rings
true for product management, for founders, for
people in the space that

are trying to figure
out is this solution solving the specific pain
point for that customer.

So you have to decide on a
specific MVP or Minimally Lovable Product as well
that tests that hypothesis.

And then you have to be
open minded in knowing that you might be proven wrong. You might invalidate
your hypothesis.

And it's an important
skill to let go of your ego

and be OK with
being proven wrong. And even if you're going in
with those preconceived notions,

it's OK if you're proven wrong. That's an important
skill that I've had

to try to train a little bit. MICHAEL LEPECH:
Yeah, that's a great. One of my colleagues
Riitta Katila

who studies successful
startups has done a lot of work

on the success
metrics of startups that use a hypothesis-based
approach towards product

development and towards growth
in which they say, look, this is our hypothesis. Let's test it. Let's see if the
customers like it.
Let's see if this helps us grow. Let's see if this is successful. If it's right, great.

If it's not correct, that's OK
too because we've learned a lot and we are going to use that
learning in our next stage.

And we talk of
course all the time in Silicon Valley about failing
fast and being OK with that.

But as with anything,
failure hurts unless you can couch it in the
idea of, this is our hypothesis.

It might be right,
it might be wrong. But whatever the outcome
is, we will have learned. We will have learned
that it's right,

we will have learned that
it's wrong, and that in itself is a success. And so I really
appreciate you making

that point that
you have to be open minded that even if your
hypothesis is proven wrong,

you as an individual
and you as a team have learned a great deal.

Definitely. So one of the other
things that I'd like to connect between
both of your lists

is something that Arya had said,
you've got to be a deep thinker. And you, Kunal, had said,
you've got to be organized.

And one of the things
that I love about the way that we structure
our programs is they're very framework driven.

Yes, we'll have great examples. Yes, we'll have case studies. Yes, we'll have all of
those types of things.

But we also try to have
every single learner leave with a set of tools
in their tool belt,

frameworks that can
help them organize their thinking regardless
of what comes their way.

We have no idea what challenges
our learners will face or we have no idea
what challenges

we will face in the next year,
next five years, next 10 years. And so when your team
comes to you with a problem

that you've never seen before,
what are they looking for? They're looking
for deep thought, they're looking
for organization,

and they're looking for
leadership from the PM. And frameworks help you provide
those things to your team .

It shows that you have
organized, clear, and deep ways of addressing problems
and thinking about them

in a structured way. And that's something
that will benefit you throughout your career
regardless of how advanced

you get in the PM role. And so I love that you
connected all of those things together through your lists.

So a couple of other-- a
couple of other things. So if you can give us an example
from just one of the three

on your list, how you use
it in your role today?

And this time, we'll
start with Kunal. KUNAL GARG: Yeah. I think, just jumping off
of that last point again.

Being decisive, I'll double
down on that example, when

we were first building out
our MVP for our first idea,

we were again in the creator
economy building for influencers and TikTokers, building a
financing product to securitize
their sponsorship agreements. So it was really cool idea. It sounded flashy.

But then we realized there
wasn't a real pain point that we were solving for our customers. We didn't really
understand our customers.

We didn't practice
that user empathy. And even though we decided
to build out a product,

we quickly decided that
we were proven wrong and we pivoted completely
into a different problem space

into data and data engineering. And that quick decision
to move fast and learn

from those mistakes
helped us a lot in terms of jumping to
a problem that actually was a pain point for
customers and practicing

that user empathy. So it allowed us
to practice some of these skills
in the real world.

And it's helped us to
move fast in that sense. MICHAEL LEPECH: Totally.

Arya, can you give
us a deeper example on how you use one of
your three top skills

in a specific example? ARYA TAYLOR: Yeah. I'm actually going to touch
on a few different skills

that we talked about
in this example. So as a PM, typically
you're mapped

to probably about
7 to 10 resources.

Seven of those are engineers,
maybe one designer, and one

analyst or something like that. In my role, I just
happened to be

mapped to 32 which poses quite
a challenge because running

a team of 32 people can be
operationally very challenging. And so I think this is where
being organized, having empathy,

and being a good communicator
all three of those really had to come into play. So I, first off, had to set
up a lot of processes in place

to make the team
operationally efficient. So each team had
leads that were point

of contact for certain things. We had to divide up
responsibilities and make sure that everyone was clear on
the boundaries in place.

The second thing was how can we
all communicate with each other. How can I make sure
that the data science

lead and the
engineering lead are all aligned and on the same
page on what we're doing.

So I set up these
weekly meetings where we have to talk
things out, talk about what are our blockers,
what are our concerns,

are there any ideas
we want to flesh out and let's do that
together as a team. And then the third thing
related to user empathy

is, how can we make sure
that we're grounded in what our customers are saying.

Given that there's 30 people
or more than 30 people on this team, how
do we how are we all going to make sure that
we're all on the same page

about what our
customers are saying. And so for that I
set up a weekly sync

where we just go through
our customer feedback. We started mapping it
to different problems that we're solving or maybe
problems that we're not solving.

And we go through
and prioritize those. So this is an example
where not only did

I have to introduce a lot of
organization into the team, but I had to make sure that I
was able to make sure not only

I'm communicating
well with everyone, but everyone is communicating
well with everyone. And we all are, at the end of
the day, grounded in our users.

MICHAEL LEPECH: Got it, cool. So I want to ask a few questions
that a little bit off the cuff

based on some of the
things you've already said. I'm going to start
with Arya here.

that strange in Silicon
Valley of a transition. How did you find
that transition?

And also, were there any
skills from your data science

background that you
specifically found important for your PM role?

ARYA TAYLOR: Yeah,
that's a great question. So the way that it all
started out actually

was when I was a data
scientist, my team just didn't have a product manager.

And so I was unknowingly playing
the role of a product manager. I was like, hey,
can I talk to users,

can I manage the
stakeholder relationships, can I design what our vision
should be for whatever model

we're building, and
so on and so forth. And then when I was having
a career conversation

with my manager, she was like,
you'd be a good product manager. And that was what turned the
light bulb on in my mind where

I was like, OK, let me
explore this further and see if this is something
that I'm interested in.

So I ended up asking if I
can do one project where

I'm the product manager
instead of a data scientist. And thankfully,
she agreed to that

and I was able to execute one
project as a product manager, see how it felt to
do that, and assess

is this the skill set that I
feel more naturally leaning toward or do I want to
stick with data science.

Sure enough, at midway
through the project, I was like, this is it. I love this. This is so much fun.

And this is the career that
I want to move forward with. So I switched into it.

And I think having the
data science background is super, super useful because
as a product manager not

only are you required
to analyze data, you're required
to figure out why

a metric is moving a certain way
and build a story from that as well.

This happened and when I dug
into it, the reason for it was this.

And now based on that, these
are the different actions we're going to take.

So it was very much useful
to just have that background

knowledge and be
able to understand a business through data
and then bring that to the role of
product management.

MICHAEL LEPECH: Totally. You've actually touched
on something that I that I end up teaching
in a lot of our programs

and it's called job
crafting, where over time you take on roles that
weren't your original job

but you enjoy doing them. And all of a sudden,
over time, it becomes your real job, which
is the best way to figure out

what your job is going to be. Kunal, I actually
want to address a question that's come in
from one of the participants.

Michael asked a question
around the PM role differing in the R&D
space and the early parts

of a company versus a more
mature and established space. And you've served in the role
in a very small company when

you're doing a lot of brand
new product development stuff. And so while that might
not be what we classically

think of as R&D, it's definitely
a form of, if not R, definitely

D. And so given that's
been your experience, how do you think
the role of the PM

is different at a very early
stage company versus one that's a little more mature
and established?

KUNAL GARG: Yeah. I think, just going
back to those skills that we talked about
earlier, it's up to you

to set up those processes
such that your team can be successful.

And you have to really set
a clear vision and strategy

for developing a hypothesis
and proving it right or wrong.

So if you come into a
larger-sized company that has reached product-market
fit and they are just

making iterations,
you probably already have a culture around how
you design PRDs or Product

Requirements Docs. You probably have a culture
around how you conduct research.

A lot of those things
probably are already set in place for your team. There's probably a
repeatable sales cycle.

A lot of those motions
are already in place. And if you are doing
product at an earlier stage,

you have a lot of
ownership there to define those for your own team.

You might even be deciding
your own ICP or Ideal Customer Profile. So there is a lot of
ownership in that.

There is more risk because
you are deciding those things. But it is super
rewarding when you

do nail it and you get it
right because you were involved in that whole conversation and
got to make those decisions.

So again, if you
can be organized, set up those processes in
place that the more enterprise

companies have, and you go
about in a regimented way,

you have the hypothesis,
you go about it in a scientific method approach,
you're primed to be successful.

MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah. I love that you're talking
about the scientific method because it's something
that, of course,

we teach at the University
as engineers, as researchers.

And of course, it's
something that many of us learn in grade school. And you think it's one
of those things that,

oh, yeah, scientific
method, OK, I'm never going to touch this
again like so many things that we learn in grade school.

And you might never end up using
again in your professional life. And the fact that we touch
back on, it's a real thing.

And that step-by-step process of
creating questions and answering those questions is
really the foundation

of how we still learn when in
fact, the outcome is uncertain. And this actually extends to
one of the questions that's

come in from Muhammad about how
do we reduce the cost, both time

and money, of experimenting
on hypotheses like this? Because if you're
going to use a question

or hypothesis-based
approach, how do you make sure that you're
not burning cash endlessly

with unsuccessful stuff? And I'd like to hear
from both of you

on what some of the
approaches are that you've found to be able to do that. Kunal, what do you think?

KUNAL GARG: I want to lean
on one of the frameworks that we talk about in the course
and that is the double diamond

framework. I think one of the biggest
learnings that folks take away from the course is you have
to start in the problem space

before you jump to
the solution space. So if you view the problem
space as one diamond

and then the solution space
is the second diamond, start in the problem
space really getting

a full understanding of
all the different problems in this domain, narrow
in on a specific problem,

then think about
all the solutions that can address that
problem, and then narrow in on one final
solution that solves it best.

The reason I bring
that up is you can save yourself so
much time and energy if you do the frontloaded
work of focusing on a problem

that people actually face. And I was not
successful with that. I did not practice that
with my own startup.

We pivoted at the beginning and
we learned from our mistakes. But I'll tell you, you'll
save so much time and energy

if you focus on
the problem first and then go to the solution.

And on top of
that, I think there are a lot of different
research methods that you can apply at every
step of that product lifecycle

to make sure you're
not jumping ahead. So you can do interviews.

You can do A/B testing. You can do a lot of things
across that whole range of research to make
sure that you're not

jumping ahead and making a
decision that's a one-way door

allowing you to kind of go
back and make small iterations instead of jumping so far ahead.

MICHAEL LEPECH: Sure. Arya, anything to add to that? ARYA TAYLOR: I think I
want to just plus one

to everything Kunal said. One of my mentors who has helped
me a lot in product management

said to me, if you've defined
the problem correctly, the solution is obvious and
that really stuck with me.

Because the hard part is really
defining the problem correctly and really knowing that it is a
problem and it's worth solving.

The solution is not really
the glitz and glam part. I actually think
the problem is where

if you can figure
that out, then you will find the right solution. So that's my only
thing that I would add.

MICHAEL LEPECH: Yeah, we always
like to tell folks, fall in love with the problem,
not the solution. And if you really
figure out the problem,

the solution that you
get will be great. This also extends a
little bit to a comment

that was made by Philip
saying that there are many frameworks
out there and how do we know which
one is going to be

the best for a specific
problem or solution. And my thoughts
on that are this,

we don't know which framework
is going to be the best. Which is why we find that
best approach is to teach you

a cadre of frameworks. I talked about it before
as kind of a tool belt

with a bunch of frameworks
that are in your tool belt ready to go. And when you confront a
problem, pick one of those

frameworks out of your
tool belt and apply it. And if it gives you insight
that is valuable in order

to lead your team-- to
lead your team forward, then it was the right framework
for that time and that place.

And if you're pulling
this framework out, and you try it out, and
it really doesn't give you any valuable insight into how to
move forward, that's cool too.

Move on to another framework
that either we've taught you or that you know from someone
else in your organization

or your experience. Because I can't say
that we know any better than anyone else about
which frameworks are exactly

applicable to which
problems, which is why we try to give
you a set of them so that you're ready for
anything that comes your way

and to apply a variety of
different organizational techniques to solving
those problems.

So I want to go back

of the steps

that are interrelated and you're looking to
